fields.value: THE POTENTIAL FOR FOREST LANDSCAPE RESTORATION IN DEGRADED FARMLANDS: Filling knowledge gaps on the restoration of degraded smallholder landscape mosaics

authorAffiliation.value: World Agroforestry Centre (ICRAF) and  Wageningen University (WUR)

dsDescriptionValue.value:
The main objective of this work package was to illustrate the utility of comparative
studies in scaling up forest landscape restoration (FLR) projects by combining systematic field-based methodologies with advanced remote sensing analyses
to provide real-time as well as past assessments of key indicators of land degradation. These methods and approaches allow for the prediction of indicators of ecosystem health to be made for large landscapes.

grantNumberAgency.value: International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)

files.description:
This report is the final technical report for work package 2 (WP2) of the DfID and IUCN- funded project “Filling Knowledge Gaps on the Restoration of Degraded Smallholder Landscape Mosaics”. The main objective of this work package was to illustrate the utility of comparative studies in scaling up forest landscape restoration (FLR) projects by combining systematic field-based methodologies with advanced remote sensing analyses to provide real-time as well as past assessments of key indicators of land degradation. These methods and approaches allow for the prediction of indicators of ecosystem health to be made for large landscapes. The report also outlines advances in soil and land health monitoring that enable efficient baseline assessments
and monitoring of impacts towards restoration of degraded forest landscapes.
files.label: ICRAF_IUCN_2015_knowfor_wp2_report_lowres.pdf

dataFile.description:
This report is the final technical report for work package 2 (WP2) of the DfID and IUCN- funded project “Filling Knowledge Gaps on the Restoration of Degraded Smallholder Landscape Mosaics”. The main objective of this work package was to illustrate the utility of comparative studies in scaling up forest landscape restoration (FLR) projects by combining systematic field-based methodologies with advanced remote sensing analyses to provide real-time as well as past assessments of key indicators of land degradation. These methods and approaches allow for the prediction of indicators of ecosystem health to be made for large landscapes. The report also outlines advances in soil and land health monitoring that enable efficient baseline assessments
and monitoring of impacts towards restoration of degraded forest landscapes.

dataFile.description: Codebook for the LDSF variables and column headers.

files.description:
The LDSF is designed to provide a biophysical baseline at landscape
level, and a monitoring and evaluation
framework for assessing processes of land degradation and the effectiveness of rehabilitation measures (recovery) over time.
files.label: ldsfFieldGuide_2013_v4 ICRAF.pdf
